text: Family Member: Right. Okay. So then if the hemoglobin is not sufficient when he comes back, for example, he gets the transfusion, he gets here, and do the lab or something, so if it’s not, then what happens? Doctor: Uh, I mean, I’ll have to look at the protocol to see, you know, what the rules are about how long the drug can be delayed. But one option would be to call it quits at that point in time and talk about additional therapies, new therapies. The second option would be to keep him off the drug for the maximum amount of time before the study, you know, would kick him out, and then to hope and pray and, and maybe even give another transfusion to make the hemoglobin. If you’re trying that hard to make the hemoglobin not drop, it probably means that it’s not in the best interest of the patient to stay on the study. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So let’s cross that bridge if we get to it. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But, but it will not be a very good sign if despite coming off the drug and the transfusion, the hemoglobin still drops. So after that point, we have a more detailed discussion about alternative options. Patient: Yes. Doctor: But let’s hope for the best. Patient: We’ll be in our faith, so we’ll keep on looking up. Doctor: Me too. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that makes two of us. Patient: Okay. We’re done? I think we got it okay. I want to make sure.

Doctor: Me too. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that makes two of us. Patient: Okay. We’re done? I think we got it okay. I want to make sure.

text: Family Member: …than chemo, correct? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: Okay. Does any others have xxx]? Doctor: I think and since his cancer has shown us over the years that it was very sensitive to hormonal therapies, I would advocate doing that – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - unless I see you know big huge lymph nodes or some xxx] in there that I’m majorly concerned about. Okay? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: The other option again for lymph nodes of a specific size and the size limitation is more because one of the studies we have requires the smallest size of the lymph node to be one point five centimeter or higher. And that is uh a combination of a medication called Cabozantinib with an immune therapy. So that combination I think I would strongly recommend looking at if you have enough disease that needs treatment. Obviously if there’s… Patient: Are you gonna be able to find that out today? Doctor: I’m hoping to, yes. So that’s why I said let’s try and get some preliminary information on your CAT scans because that is going to be the key decision maker. Patient: More so than a bone? Doctor: I think the bone scan the problem is your report compared it to I don’t know a scan done years ago, because in between all the bone scans you had were here, they were not up there…

text: Family Member: Okay. Doctor: The insurance part may take a little bit longer because, uh, I can’t, I don’t know enough about insurance to predict. It’s crazy. It’s silly. But that’s, you know. text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um many patients don’t like that term. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um so that’s just hormone resistant. Patient: Okay. Doctor: In that context only, if you give back super-high doses of testosterone to the patient, and the way that we do that is we give an intra-muscular injection. It’s an injection of testosterone into the muscle that is either thigh muscle or the butt muscle. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: In about thirty to forty percent of patients it causes remissions. In other words it causes cancer either to shrink um partially or completely in addition to the PSA level to drop either partially or completely. Patient: I don’t understand how. Could you give me the basic outline as to how that is happening? Let’s say you have the person who is overweight; you give him more food. That doesn’t – Doctor: Yeah, as I said, as you pointed out, it seems like a paradox and it seems counterintuitive. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: And the reason is it has to do with the fact that um when the prostate cancer cell, the cancer cell has been in an environment where the testosterone has been deprived for so long, and then all of a sudden you give that cell back a super-high dose of testosterone, it shocks the system and it causes that cell to die. And the exact reason for that we’ve begun to tease it out and understand it better. Patient: Uh hum.

text: Family Member: I see. Doctor: Abiraterone is probably what I would prefer. Although for you, the downsides of it is potentially, you know, fluid retention. Huh, there is a lot of fatigue related to it. Huh, huh, we have to watch your blood tests a little bit. Huh, about seventy-five percent, three out of four people, their PSA is going to drop on it. Huh, the average person’s on it for about fifteen months, then the cancer figures it out, and we have to look at maybe moving to something else. We don’t change therapy based on PSA. We base it on how you’re feeling and whether your scans show more cancer than what we saw today. Okay? Patient: Now, what would you recommend right now? Doctor: Yeah. I, I like the abiraterone but we’ll have to check to sort of see what the cost is to you. The other one doesn’t need prednisone. It makes people a little bit more frail so I’m a little bit more worried about that one in you. Huh, you know, we don’t have right offhand a clinical trial that I can think about. Our first study with abiraterone, you have to have a mutation which you don’t have. So we would just be able to give you abiraterone. Our enzalutamide plus new drug first-line study is on hold right now. Huh, the two other studies that we have all require that you have had abiraterone or enzalutamide. Huh, so usually after one of these drugs if your cancer is getting worse more options from a clinical trial perspective open up. Huh, we just finished our study of radiation and a vaccine. We don’t know if that has any activity or working yet to see whether or not, huh, that would be a standard option. Huh, you aren’t eligible, so right now, it would be the abiraterone that we would head towards. So what I typically do is send an email to our pharmacy saying can you price this out, then speak to you about whether you can afford it or not afford it, and then, huh, they work on sort of the patient assistance program, if you need it. Huh, if you don’t need it or you get one of those things, then they can provide the drug. Huh, we might have you come in and meet with that pharmacist or one of the nurse practitioners that I work with, huh, to sort of just re-go over what you may feel with starting the new drug, or that if, again, we just can’t get it for you, we can try the other one, or we would think maybe even going to the radium, which is a liquid radiation drug, which is given here in the clinic. Usually that’s what we go to next. Patient: That’s what I had before but they, radia, huh- Doctor: Rad. Patient: She injected me with something. Family Member: No. No. Doctor: You’ll continue on your hormone shots every three months for the rest of your life. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, so I’ll set that visit up for sure. Huh, and then, huh, hopefully within the next couple of weeks we’ll be able to figure out where you are and you can get started on the abiraterone. Patient: Okay. The pills that you told me to stop taking, should I go back on them?

I, I like the abiraterone but we’ll have to check to sort of see what the cost is to you. The other one doesn’t need prednisone. It makes people a little bit more frail so I’m a little bit more worried about that one in you. Huh, you know, we don’t have right offhand a clinical trial that I can think about. Our first study with abiraterone, you have to have a mutation which you don’t have. So we would just be able to give you abiraterone. Our enzalutamide plus new drug first-line study is on hold right now. Huh, the two other studies that we have all require that you have had abiraterone or enzalutamide. Huh, so usually after one of these drugs if your cancer is getting worse more options from a clinical trial perspective open up. Huh, we just finished our study of radiation and a vaccine. We don’t know if that has any activity or working yet to see whether or not, huh, that would be a standard option. Huh, you aren’t eligible, so right now, it would be the abiraterone that we would head towards. So what I typically do is send an email to our pharmacy saying can you price this out, then speak to you about whether you can afford it or not afford it, and then, huh, they work on sort of the patient assistance program, if you need it. Huh, if you don’t need it or you get one of those things, then they can provide the drug. Huh, we might have you come in and meet with that pharmacist or one of the nurse practitioners that I work with, huh, to sort of just re-go over what you may feel with starting the new drug, or that if, again, we just can’t get it for you, we can try the other one, or we would think maybe even going to the radium, which is a liquid radiation drug, which is given here in the clinic. Usually that’s what we go to next. Patient: That’s what I had before but they, radia, huh- Doctor: Rad. Patient: She injected me with something. Family Member: No. No. Doctor: You’ll continue on your hormone shots every three months for the rest of your life. Patient: Right. Doctor: Huh, so I’ll set that visit up for sure. Huh, and then, huh, hopefully within the next couple of weeks we’ll be able to figure out where you are and you can get started on the abiraterone. Patient: Okay. The pills that you told me to stop taking, should I go back on them?

text: Family Member: Like by the tenth. Doctor: And, then, we’re going to skip Dr. S_’s appointment on April sixteenth, and then we’ll just follow with me subsequently. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: And, um, um, Patient: By then, I will have had my – Doctor: I think you can get your hormone shot. Patient: My hormone shot. Doctor: I don’t know if you – if you get a hormone shot in January and it’s six months, you won’t need another one until July. So, that April version will just be a PSA check and see how we’re doing Patient: Right. Family Member: Right. Doctor: And maybe some more discussion. Family Member: Because that will be at least his third hormone shot.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
